avalancheActivity.comment: Forecast Snow Stability: Very limited snow patches remain, mainly on North through East to South-East aspects above 1000m. These will continue to consolidate and are stable. There is currently insufficient snow to warrant an avalanche forecast and no forecast will be published until conditions change. Further information on mountain conditions can be found on the SAIS Northern Cairngorms blog.
avalancheActivity.highlights: NC 19/01 Limited snow remains. No avalanche hazard.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Forecast Weather Influences: Very strong overnight South-Westerly winds easing throughout the day. No precipitation forecast. The freezing level will remain above the summits. Temperature inversion present so expect colder temperatures in the glens.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Forecast Weather Influences: It will remain dry with the freezing level around 1300m.
Observed Weather Influences: It has been a dry day with the freezing level around 1350m.
ObservedSnowStability: There is currently insufficient snow for an avalanche hazard and no avalanche reports will be published until conditions change. For further information please refer to the SAIS mountain blog.

avalancheActivity.comment: Forecast Snow Stability: Limited areas of well bonded snow may be encountered, mostly above 900 metres, mainly around corrie rims and in wind sheltered locations on some East aspects but more likely on South-East to South-West aspects. These conditions will be more prevalent in the high corries of the main Cairngorms.  The avalanche hazard will be Low.
avalancheActivity.highlights: SC 19.01.25 Limited areas of well bonded snow. Mostly E, SE, S and SW aspects above 900m. Avalanche hazard - Low.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Forecast Weather Influences: A dry day has been forecast with moderate to fresh South or South-Westerly winds. Slightly cooler conditions with the freezing level lowering to around 1000 metres for a time during the afternoon.
Observed Weather Influences: A dry, bright and sunny day with strong Southerly winds. A little cooler than previous days, with an air temperature of just under 1 degree centigrade recorded at 1150 metres at midday.
ObservedSnowStability: Generally there is very little snow but what remains is well bonded and stable. Largest areas can be found around corrie rims and in wind sheltered locations above 900 metres on some East, but more often South-East to South-West aspects. Largest areas were observed in the high corries of Beinn a\'Bhuird.  The avalanche hazard is Low.
